general_texts:
All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

THIS IS A SCREENING MAJOR. Screening majors require completion of specific preparatory coursework and/or a minimum GPA. For details on the specific screening requirements for this major, refer to the "Transfer Admission Screening Policy" below.


Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of TWO of the following courses, each with a grade of C (2.0) or better, no later than the end of the spring term prior to starting at UCSC in the fall:


ONE of the following:

  • ENVS 23 – The Physical and Chemical Environment
  • CHEM 3A – General Chemistry
  • CHEM 4A – Advanced General Chemistry: Molecular Structure and Reactivity


Plus ONE of the following:

  • AM 3 – Precalculus for the Social Sciences
  • AM 11A – Mathematical Methods for Economists I
  • MATH 3 – Precalculus
  • MATH 11A – Calculus with Applications
  • MATH 16A – Mathematics for Life Sciences
  • MATH 19A – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for courses approved to articulate to these requirements.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, prospective transfer students are strongly advised to complete the courses in the "Recommended Preparation" section below. Students who complete an articulated equivalent of CHEM 3A to satisfy the screening requirement listed above are strongly encouraged to also complete an articulated equivalent of CHEM 3B – General Chemistry (see below). Students who do not complete these preparatory courses prior to transfer may need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Visit the Environmental Studies website to learn more about this major.

This is a non-screening major: completion of specific major coursework is not required for admission. However, students are strongly encouraged to complete as many lower-division courses as possible from the "Recommended Preparation" section below to support timely degree completion.


Students applying to non-screening majors are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements prior to transfer. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.

Prior to the 2025-2026 academic year, the Ancient Studies B.A. was offered under the name Classical Studies B.A.


Although not required for admission, prospective transfer students interested in this major are encouraged to complete the articulated equivalent of the following course prior to transfer:


  • ONE lower-division survey of ancient history or literature in translation


Refer to the "Recommended Preparation" section below for courses approved to satisfy the survey of ancient history or literature in translation requirement.


Transfer students can complete the Ancient Studies major within two years, provided they successfully complete GREE 1 – Elementary Ancient Greek or LATN 1 – Elementary Latin during their first quarter at UC Santa Cruz. These courses are offered only in the fall quarter.


Students with prior knowledge of ancient Greek or Latin should consult with Ancient Studies faculty to determine whether they have satisfied any elementary language course requirements. Transfer applicants seeking winter-quarter entry will be screened by the program to verify prior knowledge of ancient Greek or Latin. To schedule this screening, please contact the Ancient Studies Director.



Additional Information for Transfer

Some background in history and in literary analysis and interpretation is desirable, but not essential. Since this is an interdisciplinary major, preparatory work in art history, history, literature, philosophy, or politics, depending on the student's interests, may also be useful.


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.


Visit the Ancient Studies website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz students may complete one or more minors, provided they can finish all required coursework within their maximum enrollment terms and credit limits. Minors are recorded on the official transcript but do not appear on the diploma. Pursuing a minor is optional and should align with a student’s academic interests and career goals.


Students do not apply for minors as part of their UC Santa Cruz admission application. Transfer students interested in a minor should reach out to the department that offers it for advising during their first quarter of enrollment.

Prior to the 2025-2026 academic year, the Ancient Studies Minor was called the Classical Studies Minor.


PREPARATION FOR THE MINOR

Students are encouraged to take elementary courses in ancient Greek or Latin language to prepare for this minor. Students who unable to complete these courses prior to transfer should plan to enroll in GREE 1 – Elementary Ancient Greek or LATN 1 – Elementary Latin during their first quarter at UC Santa Cruz. These courses are offered only in the fall quarter.


Students with prior knowledge of ancient Greek or Latin should consult with Ancient Studies Director to determine whether they have satisfied any elementary language course requirements.



Visit the Ancient Studies website to learn more about this minor.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: Ancient Studies Minor Program Statement

This is a non-screening major: completion of specific major coursework is not required for admission. However, students are strongly encouraged to complete as many lower-division courses as possible from the "Recommended Preparation" section below to support timely degree completion.


Students applying to non-screening majors are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements prior to transfer. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.

PREPARATION FOR THE MAJOR

Transfer students are strongly advised to complete two years of language study at accredited two and four year institutions. While two years of prior language study is strongly advised, transfer students should be able to complete the applied linguistics and multilingualism major in normative time as long as they place into language Level 4 (Level 5 for students entering UC Santa Cruz in the winter term) upon arrival at UC Santa Cruz.


﻿Effective the 2025–2026 academic year, UCSC no longer offers German or Portuguese language courses. Because this major requires intermediate-high proficiency in a non-English language (equivalent to two years of UCSC coursework), students who began these languages at their community college will be unable to continue them at UCSC.


Although not required for admission, transfer students are also encouraged to complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, prior to transferring:


  • LING 50: Introduction to Linguistics
  • APLX 80: Introduction to Applied Linguistics


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Please visit the Languages and Applied Linguistics website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: Applied Linguistics and Multilingualism B.A. Program Statement

All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

THIS IS A SCREENING MAJOR. Screening majors require completion of specific preparatory coursework and/or a minimum GPA. For details on the specific screening requirements for this major, refer to the "Transfer Admission Screening Policy" below.


Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of at least FIVE of the following courses, each with a grade of C (2.0) or better, no later than the end of the spring term prior to starting at UCSC in the fall:


ONE of the following:

  • AM 10 – Linear Algebra for Engineers
  • MATH 21 – Linear Algebra


Plus ONE of the following:

  • AM 20 – Ordinary Differential Equations for Engineers
  • MATH 24 – Ordinary Differential Equations


Plus ONE of the following options:

  • AM 30 – Multivariate Calculus for Engineers
  • MATH 23A – Vector Calculus AND MATH 23B – Vector Calculus


Plus BOTH of the following:

  • MATH 19A – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics
  • MATH 19B – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for courses approved to articulate to these requirements.


Note: Students who complete articulated equivalents of MATH 21 and MATH 24 are strongly encouraged to complete the self-paced MATLAB tutorial.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required major preparation courses, prospective transfer students are strongly encouraged to complete the articulated equivalents of the "Recommended Preparation" and "Additional Major Preparation" courses listed below. These courses serve as prerequisites for upper-division requirements, and students who do not complete them prior to transfer may need additional quarters to finish their degree.


Students should complete at least two courses from the "Additional Major Preparation" section most relevant to their interests:


  • Section A: Earth Sciences, Electrical and Computer Engineering, or Physics
  • Section B: Computer Science and Engineering or Electrical and Computer Engineering
  • Section C: Economics or Statistics
  • Section D: Mathematical Biology


Students are also strongly encouraged to complete a programming course in Python or C before transferring. If unavailable, a course in another programming language is acceptable to gain familiarity with general programming concepts and environments.



Additional Information for Transfer

Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or as many UC Santa Cruz general education requirements as possible before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: Applied Mathematics B.S. Program Statement

All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

THIS IS A SCREENING MAJOR. Screening majors require completion of specific preparatory coursework and/or a minimum GPA. For details on the specific screening requirements for this major, refer to the "Transfer Admission Screening Policy" below.


Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  1. PHYS 5A – Introduction to Physics I*
  2. PHYS 5B – Introduction to Physics II*
  3. PHYS 5C – Introduction to Physics III*
  4. MATH 19A – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics
  5. MATH 19B – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics
  6. MATH 23A – Vector Calculus


*PHYS 5A, PHYS 5B, and PHYS 5C must be completed with a cumulative GPA of 2.70 or higher.


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for lists of courses approved to apply to these requirements.


Winter Applicants Screening Policy

Students applying for winter quarter admission are required to complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, in addition to those required for fall transfer:


  1. PHYS 5D – Introduction to Physics IV
  2. MATH 23B – Vector Calculus


See the "Recommended Preparation" and "Additional Major Preparation Courses" sections below for lists of courses approved to apply to these requirements.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, transfer students are strongly advised to complete PHYS 5D – Introduction to Physics IV and CSE 20 – Beginning Programming in Python, or their articulated equivalents, to ensure timely graduation. Students who do not complete these preparatory course before transferring will likely need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.



Additional Information for Transfer

Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Please visit the Physics Department website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: Applied Physics B.S. Program Statement

Art & Design: Games + Playable Media B.A. Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following three courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  1. ONE Intro to 2D Concepts course (section A below)
  2. ONE Intro to 3D Concepts course (section B below)

All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

The following transfer screening policy takes effect in fall 2024 and will be mandatory for all transfer students entering UC Santa Cruz fall 2026 and later. Transfer students entering UCSC prior to fall 2026 are encouraged to complete these requirements, but will still be considered for entry into the major if they participate in a portfolio review; see additional information below.


Art B.A. Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Prospective transfer students planning on majoring in art should complete the following two lower-division courses, or their articulated equivalents, prior to transferring:


  • TWO Foundation courses
  • ART 10D – 2D Foundation
  • ART 10E – 3D Foundation
  • ART 10F – 4D Foundation


Students who do not complete two ART 10 equivalent courses before transferring to UC Santa Cruz have the option to undergo a portfolio review, detailed in the section below.



Portfolio Review

Transfer students who have not completed two ART 10 courses prior to entering UC Santa Cruz and wish to pursue art as a first or second major can participate in a portfolio review to waive this requirement. It is recommended to contact the art advisor about the portfolio review before enrolling in the first quarter. More information about the portfolio review can be found on the Art Department website.



Additional Information for Transfer

Transfer students are strongly advised to complete up to six preparatory courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below. Completing these courses will help ensure timely progress toward degree completion. Students should prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses, and may additionally choose to complete courses that satisfy UC Santa Cruz general education requirements as their time allows. For more information on incorporating general education requirements into your pre-transfer academic plan, please consult with your community college counselor.


Transfer students who have completed courses they believe are applicable to the Africa and its Diaspora, Asia and its Diaspora, Europe and the Americas, Mediterranean, Native Americas, and/or Oceania and its Diaspora requirements listed below, but are not included in the articulation agreement, may petition to have these courses apply toward their lower-division Art B.A. requirements. Students should consult with the art advisor about petitioning these courses prior to enrolling in their first quarter.



Please visit the Art Department website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: Art B.A. Program Statement

The Assistive Technology minor is designed for students who are interested in helping people with movement disabilities. The emphasis is on designing exoskeletons and robots built on two core cross-disciplinary areas: Mechatronics and Functional Anatomy. This minor cannot be combined with the Assistive Technology: Motor concentration of the former bioengineering major or the Robotics Engineering B.S. major.


Visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this minor.

All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

THIS IS A SCREENING MAJOR. Screening majors require completion of specific preparatory coursework and/or a minimum GPA. For details on the specific screening requirements for this major, refer to the "Transfer Admission Screening Policy" below.


Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

Biochemistry and Molecular Biology B.S. Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course, and a cumulative GPA of 2.50 or higher in all required screening courses, by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  • General Chemistry series
  • CHEM 8A – Organic Chemistry
  • CHEM 8B – Organic Chemistry
  • BIOL 20A – Cell and Molecular Biology
  • MATH 11A – Calculus with Applications OR MATH 19A – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for lists of courses approved to fulfill these requirements.


It is strongly recommended that community college students complete all required General Chemistry coursework for their intended major at one institution prior to transfer to UC Santa Cruz.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, transfer students are strongly advised to complete the courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below. These courses are prerequisites for upper-division courses required for the major. Students who do not complete these preparatory courses before transferring will likely need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.



Additional Information for Transfer

Prospective transfer students should prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses, and may additionally complete courses that satisfy UC Santa Cruz general education requirements as time allows. For information on incorporating general education requirements into your pre-transfer academic plan, consult with your community college counselor. 



Please visit the Chemistry & Biochemistry website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology B.S. Program Statement

UC Santa Cruz students may complete one or more minors, provided they can finish all required coursework within their maximum enrollment terms and credit limits. Minors are recorded on the official transcript but do not appear on the diploma. Pursuing a minor is optional and should align with a student’s academic interests and career goals.


Students do not apply for minors as part of their UC Santa Cruz admission application. Transfer students interested in a minor should reach out to the department that offers it for advising during their first quarter of enrollment.

The bioelectronics and biophotonics minor is designed for students in chemical, biological, environmental sciences, and biomolecular engineering to learn how to interface biological systems with electronics including sensors, actuators, and wireless communications. Introductory chemistry and physiology is desired, but not required.


Visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this minor.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: Bioelectronics and Biophotonics Minor Program Statement

The bioinformatics minor is intended primarily for bioinformatics tool users who are majoring in a biological or chemical specialty. The bioinformatics minor is also appropriate for computer science or computer engineering majors who are considering graduate work in bioinformatics. The bioinformatics minor cannot be combined with the biomolecular engineering and bioinformatics major.

It is strongly recommended that students complete all of their required General Chemistry courses at a single institution.

All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

THIS IS A SCREENING MAJOR. Screening majors require completion of specific preparatory coursework and/or a minimum GPA. For details on the specific screening requirements for this major, refer to the "Transfer Admission Screening Policy" below.


Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of at least EIGHT of the courses listed in the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below, with a cumulative GPA of 2.8 or better, no later than the end of the spring term prior to starting at UCSC in the fall.


All attempted screening courses are included in the cumulative GPA, calculated using UCSC grade point guidelines, even if more than eight screening courses are completed. For community colleges that do not issue “+” or “–” grades, grade points are assigned as follows: A = 4.0, B = 3.0, C = 2.0, D = 1.0.


Applicants are strongly encouraged to complete the articulated equivalents of the calculus, general chemistry, and organic chemistry courses listed below. Look for the “Strongly Recommended” notations attached to these courses.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

Although not required for admission, transfer students are strongly encouraged to complete at least TEN courses from "Required Major Preparation Courses" if they wish to graduate within two years. Completing organic chemistry before transfer is particularly important.


Students may substitute courses from "Required Major Preparation Courses" Group 2, sections A or B toward the eight required transfer screening courses for their specific intended major concentration:


  • Section A: Biomolecular Engineering concentration
  • Section B: Bioinformatics concentration



Additional Information for Transfer

Students are strongly encouraged to prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses and may additionally complete courses that fulfill UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring as time allows.



Visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this major.

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of the following courses, each with a grade of C (2.0) or better, no later than the end of the spring term prior to starting at UCSC in the fall:

  3. ONE of the following calculus courses:

Computer Literacy Requirement

Although not required for transfer, students may complete two courses, or their articulated equivalents, to satisfy this major's Computer Literacy requirement prior to transfer. Refer to section B of "Additional Major Preparation Courses" below for a list of courses approved to fulfill these requirements.


Students are strongly encouraged to prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses and may additionally complete courses that fulfill UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring as time allows.

UC Santa Cruz students may complete one or more minors, provided they can finish all required coursework within their maximum enrollment terms and credit limits. Minors are recorded on the official transcript but do not appear on the diploma. Pursuing a minor is optional and should align with a student’s academic interests and career goals.


Students do not apply for minors as part of their UC Santa Cruz admission application. Transfer students interested in a minor should reach out to the department that offers it for advising during their first quarter of enrollment.

It is strongly recommended that community college students complete all General Chemistry coursework for their intended major at one institution prior to transfer to UC Santa Cruz. Additionally, not all community colleges offer a full year of Organic Chemistry that matches UCSC's Organic Chemistry sequence. As a result, students may need to take some Organic Chemistry courses at UC Santa Cruz, even if they’ve completed a full year of introductory Organic Chemistry at a community college.



Please visit the Chemistry & Biochemistry website to learn more about this minor.

general_texts:
All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

THIS IS A SCREENING MAJOR. Screening majors require completion of specific preparatory coursework and/or a minimum GPA. For details on the specific screening requirements for this major, refer to the "Transfer Admission Screening Policy" below.


Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

The biochemistry concentration is designed for students who intend to pursue a career in biochemistry or in a related field such as biotechnology, and it provides an especially rigorous chemistry emphasis.


Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course, and a cumulative GPA of 2.50 or higher in all required screening courses, by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  • General Chemistry series
  • Calculus series
  • MATH 22 – Introduction to Calculus of Several Variables


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for lists of courses approved to fulfill these requirements.


It is strongly recommended that community college students complete all required General Chemistry coursework for their intended major at one institution prior to transfer to UC Santa Cruz. Additionally, not all community colleges offer a full year of Organic Chemistry that matches UCSC's Organic Chemistry sequence. As a result, students may need to take some Organic Chemistry courses at UC Santa Cruz, even if they’ve completed a full year of introductory Organic Chemistry at a community college.


Winter Applicants Screening Policy

Students applying for winter quarter admission are required to complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, in addition to those required for fall transfer:


  • CHEM 8A – Organic Chemistry
  • CHEM 8L – Organic Chemistry Laboratory


See the "Recommended Preparation" section below for a list of courses approved to apply to these requirements.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, transfer students are strongly advised to complete the courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below. These courses are prerequisites for upper-division courses required for the major. Students who do not complete these preparatory courses before transferring will likely need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.



Additional Information for Transfer

Prospective transfer students should prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses, and may additionally complete courses that satisfy UC Santa Cruz general education requirements as time allows. For information on incorporating general education requirements into your pre-transfer academic plan, consult with your community college counselor. 



Please visit the Chemistry & Biochemistry website to learn more about this major.

Transfer students who want to pursue the cognitive science major, must have applied and been admitted to UC Santa Cruz as a proposed cognitive science major.


Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of the calculus, statistics, and programming courses listed in the “Required Major Preparation Courses” section below. Each course must be completed with a grade of C (2.0) or better, and applicants must earn a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.8 across all required screening courses by the end of the spring term prior to fall enrollment.



AP Exam Score Substitutions

Qualifying AP exam scores may be used to satisfy certain required transfer screening courses. Students with qualifying exam credit for any of these courses need only earn a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.8 in the remaining required coursework. UCSC awards course credit based on the year the exam was taken. Exam credit policies are available on the Degree Progress Unit website.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required major preparation courses, prospective transfer students are strongly advised to complete PSYC 20 – Cognition: Fundamental Theories. Refer to the “Recommended Preparation” section below for courses approved to fulfill this requirement. Students who do not complete this course prior to transfer will likely require additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Visit the Psychology website to learn more about this major.

Transfer students who want to pursue the computer engineering major, must have applied and been admitted to UC Santa Cruz as a proposed computer engineering major.


Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of at least SIX of the courses listed in the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below, with a cumulative GPA of 2.8 or better, no later than the end of the spring term prior to starting at UCSC in the fall.


All attempted screening courses are included in the cumulative GPA (note: lecture and lab combinations count as one course). Courses completed via exam credit will count toward the minimum six courses required but are not included in the minimum GPA.


Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

Students who wish to graduate in two years are strongly recommended to complete all lower-division major requirements before coming to UC Santa Cruz. To earn their degree within two years after transferring, it is recommended that transfer students have completed courses transferable as PHYS 5A/PHYS 5L, PHYS 5C/PHYS 5N, MATH 19A, MATH 19B, and one of the following: MATH 23A, AM 10, MATH 21, or AM 20. In addition, completion of at least one programming course is recommended.


Additional Information for Transfer

Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or as many UC Santa Cruz general education requirements as possible before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this major.

THIS IS A SCREENING MAJOR. Screening majors require completion of specific preparatory coursework and/or a minimum GPA. For details on the specific screening requirements for this major, refer to the "Transfer Admission Screening Policy" below.


Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer (see additional program specific deadlines listed below). For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.

Transfer students who want to pursue the computer science major, must have applied and been admitted to UC Santa Cruz as a proposed computer science major.


The following transfer screening policy takes effect in fall 2024 and will be mandatory for all transfer students entering UC Santa Cruz fall 2026 and later. Transfer students entering UCSC prior to fall 2026 are encouraged to complete these requirements, but will still be considered for admission if they fulfill the 2023-2024 admissions screening requirements.


Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following five courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a combined minimum GPA of 2.8 or better by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  1. CSE 12 – Computer Systems and Assembly Language and Lab
  2. CSE 16 – Applied Discrete Mathematics
  3. CSE 30 – Programming Abstractions: Python
  4. MATH 19A – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics
  5. MATH 19B – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics


At least three of these five courses must be completed by the end of the fall term of the academic year preceding the student's planned entry to UC Santa Cruz, with a minimum 2.8 GPA in all completed Computer Science screening courses by that time. Any remaining screening courses must be completed by the end of spring prior to transfer.



Additional Information for Transfer

Transfer students are strongly recommended to complete one of the preparatory courses listed in the “Recommended Preparation” section below, as well as most general education requirements prior to arriving at UC Santa Cruz.


Transfer students who are not familiar with an object-oriented language may need to take a remedial course. Students familiar with C++ and Unix should find the transition to Python and C relatively simple.


Visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this major.

The Creative Technologies (CT) program at UC Santa Cruz welcomes transfer students. Prior to transferring, we recommend that prospective transfer students complete at least one lower-division course from each of the following categories:


  1. One introductory arts course in theory or history
  2. One practice-based, "maker"/production-oriented arts course


In the "Recommended Preparation" section below, you will find lists of courses approved to fulfill the CT major declaration coursework requirement.


Transfer students who have completed courses they believe match either of the two categories listed above, but that are not listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below, may petition to have these courses counted towards their CT major declaration requirements. Students will have an opportunity to consult with the CT advisor about their prior arts coursework before enrolling in their first quarter.


Minimum Unit Requirement

Articulated courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below that are less than 3 units may fulfill the CT major declaration coursework requirement in either category when 3 or more semester units are accrued. Students may combine different courses from the same category to reach the 3 semester unit minimum.


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Please visit the Creative Technologies website to learn more about this major.

For more information and advising on the creative technologies major, please contact the undergraduate advisor at creative@ucsc.edu.

PREPARATION FOR THE MINOR


One of the following courses in creative practice:

  • THEA 30: Introduction to Dance Theory and Technique
  • THEA 36: Introduction to Dance Making


Plus one course in cross-cultural techniques, chosen from the following:

  • THEA 31A: Dance Studio I: Asian or Asian Diasporic Practice
  • THEA 31B: Dance Studio I: Ballet
  • THEA 31C: Dance Studio I: Contemporary Dance Theory and Technique

  • THEA 80R: Bollywood Dance and Culture in India and Indian Diaspora
  • THEA 80U: Everybody Dance Now!
  • THEA 80Z: Indian Dance


The following production fundamentals course:

  • THEA 50: Fundamentals of Theater Production



Transfer students may petition to have equivalent lower-division courses taken at other schools count toward lower-division minor requirements and should consult with the Theater Arts academic advisor as early as possible regarding this possibility.


Please visit the Performance, Play & Design website to learn more about this minor.

The geophysics concentration provides quantitative, rigorous instruction in the geophysical sciences. Solid Earth geophysics is an internationally recognized field that includes seismology, geodesy, geodynamics and applied methods to image the Earth's interior. All of these subdisciplines have in common a strong mathematical, physical, and computational underpinning, and students wishing to pursue these subjects need training in mathematics, physics, and computer science as well as geosciences. This program will guide students through these fundamentals and then train them to apply the tools to problems in geophysics. Graduates will be prepared to pursue careers in natural hazard research and mitigation, the energy industry, or environmental consultancy.

The Earth and Planetary Sciences Department welcomes prospective transfer students who are prepared for the major. No major preparation courses are required prior to transfer; however, the following courses or their equivalents are recommended to ensure timely graduation:


All of the following courses:

  • MATH 11A: Calculus with Applications AND MATH 11B: Calculus with Applications
  • MATH 19A: Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics AND MATH 19B: Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics

  • EART 5: California Geology AND EART 5L: California Geology Laboratory
  • EART 10: How the Earth Works AND EART 10L: Geologic Principles Laboratory
  • EART 20: Environmental Geology AND EART 20L: Environmental Geology Laboratory


Five lower-division science courses taken from the following list (note the lecture course and its associated lab course count as one course towards the five):

  • BIOL 20A: Cell and Molecular Biology
  • BIOE 20B: Development and Physiology
  • BIOE 20C: Ecology and Evolution
  • CHEM 3A: General Chemistry
  • CHEM 3B/3BL: General Chemistry and Lab
  • CHEM 3C/3CL: General Chemistry and Lab
  • CHEM 4A/4AL: Advanced General Chemistry: Molecular Structure and Reactivity and Lab
  • CHEM 4B/4BL: Advanced General Chemistry: Molecular Structure and Reactivity and Lab

  • PHYS 5B/5M: Introduction to Physics II and Introduction to Physics II Laboratory

PREPARATION FOR THE MINOR

Transfer students interested in this minor are encouraged to complete the articulated equivalents of TWO of the following courses prior to transfer:


ONE of the following:

  • CHIN 1 – First-Year Chinese
  • JAPN 1 – First-Year Japanese


ONE of the following:

  • HIS 40A – Early Modern East Asia
  • HIS 40B – The Making of Modern East Asia


Refer to the "Preparation for the Minor" section below for courses approved to articulate to these requirements.



LANGUAGE REQUIREMENT

All East Asian Studies minors are expected to gain proficiency in Chinese or Japanese language. Students with prior knowledge of Chinese or Japanese are required to complete a language placement exam to determine which UCSC course of Chinese or Japanese language instruction best suits their skill level. Instructions for the placement exam may be found on the Languages and Applied Linguistics website. Students may also pursue study abroad opportunities as a way of acquiring Chinese or Japanese language instruction.



Visit the East Asian Studies website to learn more about this minor.

The Education Minor explores the history of educational thought and philosophy, the politics and economics of education, theories of cognition, learning, and pedagogy, and issues of cultural and linguistic diversity in education. It is designed to provide opportunities to examine basic questions, theories, practices, and research in the field of education. Although a Minor in Education does not confer or necessarily lead to a California Teaching Credential, it provides a foundation and experience for graduate programs, such as UCSC's Masters/Credential Program.


PREPARATION FOR THE MINOR

This is a non-screening major: completion of specific major coursework is not required for admission. However, students are strongly encouraged to complete as many lower-division courses as possible from the "Recommended Preparation" section below to support timely degree completion.


Students applying to non-screening majors are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements prior to transfer. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.

PREPARATION FOR THE MAJOR


Although not required for admission, transfer students are encouraged to complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, prior to transferring:


  1. EDUC 10 – Introduction to Learning
  2. EDUC 60 – Schooling, Democracy, and Justice


Introductory education courses completed by transfer students at their prior institution will be reviewed to determine equivalency for EDUC 10 and EDUC 60. To ensure that students desiring a transfer to UCSC's EDJ major are on track for meeting these goals, they need to connect with their community college or university advisors for guidance and course planning.


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Please visit the Education Department website to learn more about this major.

Transfer students who want to pursue the electrical engineering major, must have applied and been admitted to UC Santa Cruz as a proposed electrical engineering major.


The following transfer screening policy takes effect in fall 2024 and will be mandatory for all transfer students entering UC Santa Cruz fall 2026 and later. Transfer students entering UCSC prior to fall 2026 are encouraged to complete these requirements, but will still be considered for admission if they fulfill the 2023-2024 admissions screening requirements.


The Electrical Engineering B.S. program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.


Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of the courses listed in the “Required Major Preparation Courses” section below. Each course must be completed with a grade of C (2.0) or better, and applicants must earn a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.8 across all required screening courses by the end of the spring term prior to fall enrollment.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required major preparation courses, prospective transfer students are strongly advised to complete the articulated equivalents of the "Recommended Preparation" courses listed below. Students who do not complete these preparatory courses prior to transfer may need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.



Additional Information for Transfer

Students are strongly encouraged to prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses and may additionally complete courses that fulfill UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring as time allows.



Visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz students may complete one or more minors, provided they can finish all required coursework within their maximum enrollment terms and credit limits. Minors are recorded on the official transcript but do not appear on the diploma. Pursuing a minor is optional and should align with a student’s academic interests and career goals.


Students do not apply for minors as part of their UC Santa Cruz admission application. Transfer students interested in a minor should reach out to the department that offers it for advising during their first quarter of enrollment.

The electrical engineering minor provides a solid foundation in the core areas of electronic circuits and signals and systems, as well as the prerequisite material in mathematics and physics. This minor is particularly suitable for students with majors in applied physics or any Baskin Engineering major.


Visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this minor.

Environmental Sciences B.S. Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


One of the following options:


  • CHEM 3A: General Chemistry AND CHEM 3B: General Chemistry AND CHEM 3BL: General Chemistry Lab AND CHEM 3C: General Chemistry AND CHEM 3CL: General Chemistry Lab
  • CHEM 4A: Advanced General Chemistry: Molecular Structure and Reactivity AND CHEM 4AL: Advanced General Chemistry Lab AND CHEM 4B: Advanced General Chemistry: Molecular Structure and Reactivity AND CHEM 4BL: Advanced General Chemistry Lab


It is strongly recommended that community college students complete all required General Chemistry coursework for their intended major at one institution prior to transfer to UC Santa Cruz.


Plus these courses:

  • MATH 11A: Calculus with Applications
  • MATH 11B: Calculus with Applications
  • PHYS 6A: Introductory Physics I AND PHYS 6L: Introductory Physics I Laboratory


Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, prospective transfer students are strongly advised to complete the courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below. Students who do not complete these preparatory courses before transferring will likely need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.



Please visit the Environmental Sciences Major website to learn more about this major.

PREPARATION FOR THE MAJOR

Although not required for admission, transfer students are encouraged to complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, prior to transferring:


  1. FILM 20A – Introduction to Film Studies
  2. ONE lower-division Film and Digital Media course


Refer to the "Recommended Preparation" and "Additional Major Preparation Courses" sections below for lists of courses approved to fulfill these requirements.


A maximum of two courses from another institution may be substituted if articulated through assist.org or approved by Film and Digital Media faculty. At least one of the major qualification courses must be taken at UCSC. FILM 20P cannot be used toward declaring the major.



Additional Information for Transfer

Transfer students can finish the Film and Digital Media general major requirements within two years. While not required for admission, students are encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult with your community college counselor.


Integrated Critical Practice Concentration

In addition to the general Film and Digital Media major, students may choose to pursue the Integrated Critical Practice Concentration (ICPC). This concentration offers a more rigorous pathway, tailored for seniors with exceptional abilities in both critical studies and production. It provides exclusive classes designed for those who aim to integrate creative and scholarly work at an advanced level. Students are eligible to apply for the concentration in the last quarter of their junior year.



Please visit the Film & Digital Media Department website to learn more about this major.

The Global and Community Health (GCH) program at UC Santa Cruz welcomes transfer students. Prospective students interested in majoring in the GCH B.A. are encouraged to complete the following lower-division courses, or their articulated equivalents, prior to transferring:


  1. GCH 1 – Foundations for Global and Community Health (see group 1 below)
  2. ONE natural science and bio-environmental competency course (see group 2 below)
  3. ONE social science and political-cultural competency course (see group 3 below)
  4. Quantitative competency (see group 4 below)
  5. Language competency
  6. To fulfill the language competency requirement for the GCH B.A., students must complete one year (three quarters or two semesters) of college-level language study in a single language. All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

THIS IS A SCREENING MAJOR. Screening majors require completion of specific preparatory coursework and/or a minimum GPA. For details on the specific screening requirements for this major, refer to the "Transfer Admission Screening Policy" below.


Additional coursework listed under "Recommended Preparation" is not required for admission but is strongly recommended to support timely degree completion.


For more information, including a list of screening majors and non-screening majors, visit the UCSC Admissions website.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of the following courses, each with a grade of C (2.0) or better, no later than the end of the spring term prior to starting at UCSC in the fall:


  • General Chemistry series
  • See "General Chemistry Series" below for important information
  • CHEM 8A – Organic Chemistry
  • BIOL 20A – Cell and Molecular Biology
  • BIOL 20L – Experimental Biology Laboratory
  • BIOL 20L is not required for students who have completed BIOL 20A and BIOE 20B articulated equivalents at California Community Colleges.
  • BIOE 20B – Development and Physiology
  • One calculus course


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for courses approved to articulate to these requirements.


It is strongly recommended that community college students complete all required General Chemistry coursework for their intended major at one institution prior to transfer to UC Santa Cruz.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, transfer students are strongly advised to complete the courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below, especially CHEM 8B – Organic Chemistry, and CHEM 8L – Organic Chemistry Laboratory. These courses serve as prerequisites for upper-division requirements, and students who do not complete them prior to transfer may need additional quarters to finish their degree.



Additional Information for Transfer

Prospective transfer students should prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses, and may additionally complete courses that satisfy UC Santa Cruz general education requirements as time allows. For information on incorporating general education requirements into your pre-transfer academic plan, consult with your community college counselor. 



Please visit the Global and Community Health website to learn more about this major.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

Global Economics B.A. Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following three courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course, and a cumulative minimum GPA of 2.8 in all required screening courses, by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  1. ECON 1 – Introductory Microeconomics: Resource Allocation and Market Structure
  2. ECON 2 – Introductory Macroeconomics: Aggregate Economic Activity
  3. ONE of the following calculus courses:
  • AM 11A – Mathematical Methods for Economists I
  • MATH 11A – Calculus with Applications
  • MATH 19A – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for lists of courses approved to fulfill these requirements.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, transfer students are strongly advised to complete the courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below. These courses are prerequisites for upper-division courses required for the major. Students who do not complete these preparatory courses before transferring will likely need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.


Language Requirement

The Global Economics B.A. requires a minimum of two years of study in a language relevant to the student’s chosen regional area of interest. Fluency in a language other than English is essential for students planning to engage in the global economy. Transfer students who meet the screening criteria outlined above and have completed two years of language study can complete the major within two years of transferring to UC Santa Cruz. For more details, refer to the Academic Planner section under the "Requirements and Planners" tab in the UC Santa Cruz General Catalog.



Additional Information for Transfer

Students are strongly encouraged to prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses and may additionally complete courses that fulfill UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring as time allows.



Please visit the Economics website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: Global Economics B.A. Program Statement

This is a non-screening major: completion of specific major coursework is not required for admission. However, students are strongly encouraged to complete as many lower-division courses as possible from the "Recommended Preparation" section below to support timely degree completion.


Students applying to non-screening majors are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements prior to transfer. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.

Transfer students are enthusiastically encouraged to study history at UC Santa Cruz. Although not required for admission, prospective transfer students interested in this major are encouraged to complete the articulated equivalents of THREE unique lower-division courses prior to transfer:


  • ONE Americas and Africa course (section A below)
  • ONE Asia and the Pacific course (section B below)
  • ONE Europe and the Mediterranean World course (section C below)


Refer to the "Recommended Preparation" section below for courses approved to satisfy each of the geographic regions listed above. If a course appears under multiple regions, such as World History courses, it may be applied to only one geographic region requirement for the history major.


Distribution Requirements: At least one course fulfilling a history major requirement must be set in a time period before 600 C.E., and two additional courses must be set in periods prior to the year 1800 C.E. Refer to the "Recommended Preparation" section below for courses additionally approved to satisfy the Pre-600 C.E. and Pre-1800 C.E. requirements.


The History Department Articulation Agreement should be referenced in conjunction with this major agreement. The department agreement additionally lists courses approved to articulate to specific UCSC history courses.



Additional Information for Transfer

Petitioning Courses: Transfer students who have completed UC-transferable college-level courses they believe are applicable to the geographic regions and/or distribution requirements listed above, but are not listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below, may petition to have these courses counted towards their history major requirements. Students should consult with the history advisor about petitioning these courses before enrolling in their first quarter. It is recommended that students save their course syllabi for departmental review.


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Visit the History website to learn more about this major.

UC Santa Cruz General Catalog: History B.A. Program Statement

Students do not apply for minors as part of their UC Santa Cruz admission application. Transfer students interested in a minor should reach out to the department that offers it for advising during their first quarter of enrollment.

Transfer students may apply up to THREE lower-division history courses completed at a California Community College (CCC) toward the history minor requirements.

Since this is an interdisciplinary major, preparatory work in art history, philosophy, or politics, depending on the student’s interests, may also be useful.

Students in other languages may be able to complete the major in two years if they have completed their general education requirements prior to transfer. Transfer students admitted to UC Santa Cruz for the winter term who do not place into Level 2 or higher in a language placement test when they matriculate may not be able to complete the major in a timely manner.


Effective the 2025–2026 academic year, UCSC no longer offers German or Portuguese language courses. Because this major requires intermediate-high proficiency in a non-English language (equivalent to two years of UCSC coursework), students who began these languages at their community college will be unable to continue them at UCSC.

All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

This is a non-screening major: completion of specific major coursework is not required for admission. However, students are strongly encouraged to complete as many lower-division courses as possible from the "Recommended Preparation" section below to support timely degree completion.


Students applying to non-screening majors are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements prior to transfer. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.

PREPARATION FOR THE MAJOR

Although not required for admission, transfer students are encouraged to complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, prior to transferring:


  • LING 50: Introduction to Linguistics
  • LING 53: Semantics I


FOREIGN LANGUAGE/MATHEMATICS/COMPUTER SCIENCE COMPETENCY REQUIREMENT

Linguistics majors are required to demonstrate competency in either foreign language or mathematics/computer science.


While not required for selection, transfer students are strongly encouraged to complete as much preparation as possible in the foreign language of their choosing. Transfer students admitted to UC Santa Cruz for the winter term who do not place into Level 2 or higher in a language placement test when they enter UC Santa Cruz may not be able to complete the major in a timely manner. Bear in mind that placement exams, and the resulting credit for the major, are only available for languages taught at UC Santa Cruz. If you expect to test out of level 5 in your chosen language or plan to complete the Mathematics/Computer Science competency requirement, you need not enroll in a language course. 


Effective the 2025–2026 academic year, UCSC no longer offers German or Portuguese language courses. Because this major requires intermediate-high proficiency in a non-English language (equivalent to two years of UCSC coursework), students who began these languages at their community college will be unable to continue them at UCSC.


Students with a strong formal background can choose to satisfy the mathematics/computer science competency requirement by demonstrating sufficient preparation in mathematics for advanced formal work in linguistics.


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Please visit the Linguistics website to learn more about this major.

Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  • BIOL 20A – Cell and Molecular Biology
  • BIOE 20B – Development and Physiology
  • BIOE 20C – Ecology and Evolution
  • One approved mathematics course
  • General Chemistry (select one of the following options):
  • CHEM 3A – General Chemistry AND CHEM 3B – General Chemistry
  • CHEM 4A – Advanced General Chemistry: Molecular Structure and Reactivity


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for lists of courses approved to fulfill these requirements.

﻿

It is strongly recommended that community college students complete all required General Chemistry coursework for their intended major at one institution prior to transfer to UC Santa Cruz.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, transfer students are strongly advised to complete the courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below. These courses are prerequisites for upper-division courses required for this major. Students who do not complete these preparatory courses before transferring will likely need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.



Visit the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology website to learn more about this major.

The Mathematics Theory and Computation B.S. is intended to prepare students for technical careers in industry or government while providing a solid mathematical background.﻿

Transfer students must complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:

The Microbiology B.S. is designed for students interested in careers in biomedical, environmental, and basic science fields in both industry and academia. As a unique feature of this program, students take a microbiology course with a focus on evaluating relevant scientific articles.


Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better in each course by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  • General Chemistry series
  • CHEM 8A – Organic Chemistry
  • BIOL 20A – Cell and Molecular Biology
  • BIOL 20L – Experimental Biology Laboratory
  • BIOL 20L is not required for students who have completed BIOL 20A and BIOE 20B articulated equivalents at California Community Colleges.
  • BIOE 20B – Development and Physiology
  • One math course:
  • MATH 11A – Calculus with Applications
  • MATH 16A – Mathematics for Life and Environmental Sciences
  • MATH 19A – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for lists of courses approved to fulfill these requirements.


It is strongly recommended that community college students complete all required General Chemistry coursework for their intended major at one institution prior to transfer to UC Santa Cruz.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, transfer students are strongly advised to complete the courses listed in the "Recommended Preparation" section below, especially the following:


  • CHEM 8B – Organic Chemistry
  • CHEM 8L – Organic Chemistry Laboratory
  • MATH 11B – Calculus with Applications OR MATH 16B – Mathematics for Life and Environmental Sciences OR MATH 19B – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics
  • STAT 5 – Statistics OR STAT 7 – Statistical Methods for the Biological, Environmental, and Health Sciences & STAT 7L – Statistical Methods for the Biological, Environmental, and Health Sciences Laboratory


These courses are prerequisites for upper-division courses required for this major. Students who do not complete these preparatory courses before transferring will likely need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.



Additional Information for Transfer

Prospective transfer students should prioritize required and recommended major preparation courses, and may additionally complete courses that satisfy UC Santa Cruz general education requirements as time allows. For information on incorporating general education requirements into your pre-transfer academic plan, consult with your community college counselor.


Visit the Microbiology and Environmental Toxicology website to learn more about this major.

general_texts:
The Middle Eastern and North African Studies (MENAS) minor, administered by the Humanities Division in partnership with the Center for the Middle East and North Africa (CMENA), supports the development of a robust knowledge of the Middle East and North Africa through a program that consists of a diverse set of courses across departments and divisions as well as the study of at least one regional language. The objective of the MENAS minor is to promote substantive regional knowledge, understanding, and curiosity among students who are interested in positioning themselves as global citizens.


PREPARATION FOR THE MINOR

The minor requires completion of at least three quarters of language instruction in Arabic or Hebrew and one specified lower-division introductory course. Refer to the "Preparation for the Minor" section below for a list of courses approved to fulfill the introductory requirement.



Please visit the Middle Eastern and North African Studies (MENAS) Minor webpage to learn more about this minor.

This is a non-screening major: completion of specific major coursework is not required for admission. However, students are strongly encouraged to complete as many lower-division courses as possible from the "Recommended Preparation" section below to support timely degree completion.

Prospective transfer students are strongly encouraged to contact the Music Undergraduate Programs Coordinator <music@ucsc.edu> to schedule a Zoom or phone advising appointment prior to applying.


PREPARATION FOR THE MAJOR

Theory

The Music Department encourages transfer students to take the Theory Placement Exam and seek academic counseling before transfer the year before they apply, as placement results have the potential to affect time-to-degree for students, depending on major track requirements. Placement results are valid for a calendar year.


Although not required for admission, prospective transfer students are encouraged to complete college-level music theory courses prior to transferring. Refer to the "Recommended Preparation" section below for courses approved to articulate to the major’s Western music theory requirements.


Performance

Students are encouraged to begin performing ensembles and/or applied lessons on a specific instrument or voice before transfer. Upon transfer, community college ensemble and lesson participation can be petitioned to count toward the major requirements.



Additional Information for Transfer

Students are encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Visit the Music Department website to learn more about this major.

Prospective transfer students interested in majoring in philosophy are strongly encouraged to complete two lower-division philosophy courses, or their articulated equivalents, prior to transferring:


  1. PHIL 9 – Introductory Symbolic Logic
  2. One additional lower-division philosophy course


Refer to the "Recommended Preparation" section below for courses approved to apply to each of the requirements listed above.


Students who cannot enroll in the articulated equivalent of PHIL 9 at a California Community College are strongly encouraged to take PHIL 9 at UC Santa Cruz before their first fall quarter. PHIL 9 is offered online during a 10-week summer session. For more information, please visit the UC Santa Cruz Summer Edge webpage.



Additional Information for Transfer

Petitioning Courses: Transfer students who have completed courses in the topics listed below, but which are not included in the "Recommended Preparation" section, may petition to have these courses count toward the second lower-division philosophy course requirement:


  • Introduction to Symbolic Logic
  • Ancient Philosophy
  • Modern Philosophy
  • Ethical Theory
  • Philosophy of Mind or Epistemology


Students should consult with the philosophy advisor about petitioning courses prior to enrolling in their first quarter.



Please visit the Philosophy website to learn more about this major.
