Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  1. PHYS 5A – Introduction to Physics I*
  2. PHYS 5B – Introduction to Physics II*
  3. PHYS 5C – Introduction to Physics III*
  4. MATH 19A – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics
  5. MATH 19B – Calculus for Science, Engineering, and Mathematics
  6. MATH 23A – Vector Calculus


*PHYS 5A, PHYS 5B, and PHYS 5C must be completed with a cumulative GPA of 2.70 or higher.


Refer to the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below for lists of courses approved to apply to these requirements.


Winter Applicants Screening Policy

Students applying for winter quarter admission are required to complete the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, in addition to those required for fall transfer:


  1. PHYS 5D – Introduction to Physics IV
  2. MATH 23B – Vector Calculus


See the "Recommended Preparation" and "Additional Major Preparation Courses" sections below for lists of courses approved to apply to these requirements.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the required courses listed above, transfer students are strongly advised to complete PHYS 5D – Introduction to Physics IV, or its articulated equivalent, to ensure timely graduation. Students who do not complete this preparatory course before transferring will likely need additional quarters of enrollment to complete their degree.



Additional Information for Transfer

Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Please visit the Physics Department website to learn more about this major.

Transfer students who want to pursue the psychology major (general or intensive), must have applied and been admitted to UC Santa Cruz as a proposed psychology major.

Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of the courses listed in the “Required Major Preparation Courses” section below, earning at least the minimum grade specified for each category by the end of the spring term prior to fall enrollment:


  • Introduction to Psychology: minimum grade of B- (2.7)*
  • Statistics: minimum grade of B- (2.7)
  • Mathematics: minimum grade of C (2.0)


*If a grade of C (2.0) or C+ (2.3) is earned in a course articulated to PSYC 1, the student must earn a minimum grade of B– (2.7) in a course articulated to PSYC 10 or PSYC 20. Refer to the “Recommended Preparation” section below for courses approved to fulfill these requirements.



AP Exam Score Substitutions

Qualifying AP exam scores may be used to satisfy certain required transfer screening courses. UCSC awards course credit based on the year the exam was taken. Exam credit policies are available on the Degree Progress Unit website.

This major is intended for students who are interested in teaching science in high schools in the state of California. 


Science Education B.S. Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer students must complete a minimum of six of the following courses, or their articulated equivalents, with a grade of C (2.0) or better by the end of the spring term prior to transferring in the fall:


  • BIOE 20B: Development and Physiology
  • BIOE 20C: Ecology and Evolution
  • BIOL 20A: Cell and Molecular Biology
  • MATH 11A: Calculus with Applications
  • MATH 11B: Calculus with Applications
  • PHYS 6A: Introductory Physics I
  • PHYS 6B: Introductory Physics II
  • PHYS 6C: Introductory Physics III
  • STAT 5: Statistics
  • CHEM 3A: General Chemistry*
  • CHEM 3B: General Chemistry*
  • CHEM 3C: General Chemistry*
  • CHEM 4A: Advanced General Chemistry: Molecular Structure and Reactivity*
  • CHEM 4B: Advanced General Chemistry: Molecular Structure and Reactivity*


*Courses from either the CHEM 3 series or the CHEM 4 series, not both, may be used. It is strongly recommended that community college students complete all General Chemistry coursework for their intended major at one institution prior to transfer to UC Santa Cruz.



Strongly Recommended Major Preparation

In addition to the six courses required for admission, students are strongly recommended to complete three additional courses from the above course list prior to transfer to ensure timely graduation.



Additional Information for Transfer

Prospective students are encouraged to prioritize required and recommended major preparation, and may additionally complete courses that articulate to UC Santa Cruz general education requirements as time allows.



Please visit the Physics Department website to learn more about this major.

Transfer students are strongly encouraged to complete two years of Spanish language study at an accredited two- or four-year institution. Transfer Admission Screening Policy

Transfer applicants must complete the articulated equivalents of at least SIX of the courses listed in the "Required Major Preparation Courses" section below, with a cumulative GPA of 2.4 or better, no later than the end of the spring term prior to starting at UCSC in the fall.


All attempted screening courses are included in the cumulative GPA. Courses completed via exam credit will count toward the minimum six courses required but are not included in the minimum GPA.


While students may select any six courses from the list, it is strongly recommended that at least one be chosen from Computer Science and Engineering (CSE). Students planning to complete the degree within two years are advised to complete all screening courses except TIM 50, CSE 12, and CSE 13S.



Additional Information for Transfer

Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Please visit the Baskin Engineering Undergraduate Experience website to learn more about this major.

Minors are recorded on the official transcript but do not appear on the diploma. Pursuing a minor is optional and should align with a student’s academic interests and career goals.


Students do not apply for minors as part of their UC Santa Cruz admission application. Transfer students interested in a minor should reach out to the department that offers it for advising during their first quarter of enrollment.

general_texts:
All transfer applicants must meet the University of California admissions eligibility requirements and the campus’s admission selection criteria. All requirements must be completed by the end of the spring term prior to transfer. For more information on UC admissions eligibility and admission to UC Santa Cruz, visit the Admissions website.


The UC Santa Cruz Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG) is a formal agreement that guarantees your fall admission to your chosen major, provided you are transferring from a California Community College and meet specific requirements. Visit the UC Santa Cruz TAG webpage for more information.

Some Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate Higher Level (IBH), and Advanced Level (A-level) exams satisfy UCSC course requirements. UCSC's exam credit policies may be found on the Degree Progress Unit website.

This is a non-screening major: completion of specific major coursework is not required for admission. However, students are strongly encouraged to complete as many lower-division courses as possible from the "Recommended Preparation" section below to support timely degree completion.


Students applying to non-screening majors are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements prior to transfer. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.

PREPARATION FOR THE MAJOR


Students planning to pursue the Theater Arts major are not required to audition, submit a portfolio, or complete specific major preparation courses for consideration of admission to UC Santa Cruz. Although not required for admission, transfer students are encouraged to complete courses that articulate specifically to UC Santa Cruz lower-division theater arts courses prior to transferring. Refer to the "Recommended Preparation" section below for lists of courses approved to fulfill these requirements.


Students are also encouraged to complete the California General Education Transfer Curriculum (Cal-GETC) or all UC Santa Cruz general education requirements before transferring. For guidance on incorporating Cal-GETC into your academic plan, consult your community college counselor.



Please visit the Performance, Play & Design website to learn more about this major.

general_texts:
UC Santa Cruz students may complete one or more minors, provided they can finish all required coursework within their maximum enrollment terms and credit limits. Minors are recorded on the official transcript but do not appear on the diploma. Pursuing a minor is optional and should align with a student’s academic interests and career goals.


Students do not apply for minors as part of their UC Santa Cruz admission application. Transfer students interested in a minor should reach out to the department that offers it for advising during their first quarter of enrollment.

PREPARATION FOR THE MINOR


The following fundamentals course:

  • THEA 50: Fundamentals of Theater Production


One course from the following series:

  • THEA 61A: Ancient and Medieval Drama
  • THEA 61B: Drama from the Renaissance to the Modern Age
  • THEA 61C: The Birth of the Modern: Drama and Performance After the Renaissance


Plus one course in the student's area of focus chosen from the following:

  • THEA 10: Introduction to Theater Design and Technology
  • THEA 20: Introductory Studies in Acting
  • THEA 21: Acting Studio I: Psychological Realism
  • THEA 30: Introduction to Dance Theory and Technique
  • THEA 31A: Dance Studio I: Asian or Asian Diasporic Practice
  • THEA 31B: Dance Studio I: Ballet
  • THEA 31C: Dance Studio I: Contemporary Dance Theory and Technique
  • THEA 33C: Dance Studio I
  • THEA 36: Introduction to Dance Making
  • THEA 37: African Dance
  • THEA 40: Introduction to Directing
  • THEA 80Z: Indian Dance



Please visit the Performance, Play & Design website to learn more about this minor.

UC Santa Cruz students may complete one or more minors, provided they can finish all required coursework within their maximum enrollment terms and credit limits. Minors are recorded on the official transcript but do not appear on the diploma. Pursuing a minor is optional and should align with a student’s academic interests and career goals.


Students do not apply for minors as part of their UC Santa Cruz admission application. Transfer students interested in a minor should reach out to the department that offers it for advising during their first quarter of enrollment.

Transfer students interested in this minor are encouraged to complete the articulated equivalents of the courses listed in the "Preparation for the Minor" section below prior to transfer.


Theory Preparation

The Music Department encourages transfer students to take the Theory Placement Exam and seek academic counseling before starting classes at UC Santa Cruz.


Performance Preparation

Students are encouraged to begin performing ensembles and applied lessons on a specific instrument or voice before transfer. Upon transfer, community college ensemble and lesson participation can be petitioned to count toward the minor requirements.


Visit the Music Department website to learn more about this minor.
